text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with another episode of follow the
sour dough day
7 we need dough here we go my sponge is
ready it's totally spongy it I left it
overnight as my post yesterday explained
so it's probably even more bubbly than
yours is going to be but anyway so I'm
going to knock it down with a spatula
because I need 2 cups of sponge for my
recipe if you don't knock it down you'll
get too many bubbles and it won't be
measured right so 2 cups of sponge throw
it in a bowl 2 teaspoons of salt half a
teaspoon of sugar 2 tablespoons of oil
I'm using a nice kind of a light olive
oil and then one cup of our white
unbleached bread flour we're going to
stir that together that's going to mix
in all the salt and sugar and oil and
it's going to form a very wet very
sticky dough we're going to put in
another 1/2 cup of flour we're going to
stir that in with a spatula and that's
going to form a slightly less sticky
ball of dough so once a cup and a half
of flour are in there you're going to
turn that out onto a floured board
you're going to pour 1/2 a cup of flour
over and under and you're going to work
it in with your fingertips now we're
going to get in anywhere between two and
a half and three cups of flour into this
finished bread dough so this 1/2 cup
you're going to work in and it's
probably going to still be very sticky
so just keep pushing it and kneading it
and I'm showing you my patented kneading
technique I call it the HT pp it's the
1/2 turn with the palm push so it's the
HT pp half turn pound push half turn
pound push and that's just you know
stretches out the gluten and starts to
build up the texture of the dough so
what you're going to do after those two
cups are in because we started with a
cup and then we added 1/2 cup then we
added 1/2 cup so once the two cups of
flour worked in you're going to just
keep kneading and you're going to
sprinkle a little bit of flour at a time
only when it starts sticking to the
board and/or your hands you're going to
keep doing that keep doing that and your
proud
going to work in about another half a
cup to a cup of flour it all depends on
the humidity in the dough and and the
the flour and all that kind of stuff but
the last half cup or so it's just a
sprinkle at a time you keep kneading you
keep kneading you keep kneading until
you have a very elastic springy backi
dough now here's how you can tell for
sure
get yourself a flashlight you're going
to tear off a little ball of dough and
you're going to stretch it between your
fingers and if you can stretch it so
thin that you can see the flashlight
through it and it doesn't tear then it's
done if it tears then you've got to keep
kneading all right so I took you know
between 10 and 15 minutes a pretty
heavy-duty kneading and you know I'm
pretty ripped my arms are go above
average and strength and definition so
it took me you know a good 12 15 minutes
to need that to that state once that's
done you're going to put that in a bowl
with some oil okay a little bit olive
oil just a few drips you're going to
coat it with oil you're going to throw a
kitchen towel over it and you're going
to let it rise until it doubles in size
now sourdough rises much slower than
regular dunk so I'm going to leave this
overnight and it's going to take
anywhere between you know six and now 12
hours or so and once it doubles we're
going to bake it and that'll be the last
episode by the way don't throw away the
leftover sponge put it in refrigerator
stay tuned check the site for more
details and enjoy
you
